back: A multi-dimensional table of numbers that supports a standard set of operations.
A two-dimensional array. If the matrix has $m$ rows and $n$ columns, we say it is an $m \times n$ matrix or $m \times n$ array.
A square matrix (two-dimensional array) for which the only non-zero entries are along the main diagonal.

A square $m \times m$ matrix (two-dimensional array) is an upper triangular matrix if its only nonzero elements are in the main diagonal and above; in other words, the only nonzero elements are those at positions $k,l$ that satisfy $l \ge k$.

A square $m \times m$ matrix (two-dimensional array) is an upper triangular matrix if its only nonzero elements are in the main diagonal and below; in other words, the only nonzero elements are those at positions $k,l$ that satisfy $l \le k$.
A square $m \times m$ matrix (two-dimensional array) that is an upper triangular matrix or lower triangular matrix.
A diagonal matrix with 1s on the diagonal. The $m \times m$ identity matrix is denoted $\mathbf{I}_m$.
